questions.text: A 19-year-old pregnant woman at 21 weeks of gestation has the following finding on USG. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given prenatal ultrasound image showing irregular loops of bowel outside the abdominal cavity without an overlying sac is suggestive of Gastroschisis.

Gastroschisis represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. The abdominal defect is located usually to the right of the umbilicus at the junction of the umbilicus and normal skin. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. It is usually <4cm in size without an overlying sac.

Gastroschisis is commonly associated with intestinal atresia. The intestine is thickened, edematous and foreshortened in gastroschisis as the intestine is directly exposed to the amniotic fluid in utero due to the absence of an overlying sac. 

Gastroschisis can be diagnosed by a prenatal ultrasound scan. 

Below is the prenatal ultrasound image showing irregular loops of bowel outside the abdominal cavity without an overlying sac. 

Treatment: All newborns with gastroschisis require urgent surgical treatment. IV fluids are administered to counter the significant evaporative fluid losses. The reduction of the bowel is staged using a silo-plastic bag that is attached to the abdominal wall containing the herniated bowel that is gently reduced every 12-24 hours. Surgical closure can be done within approximately 1 to 2 weeks. 

Other options:

Option a : Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where the bowel and the solid viscera are covered by the peritoneum and amniotic membrane. It occurs from a small size with intestinal contents to giant omphaloceles which have >4 cm abdominal wall defect. Below is the image of an infant with omphalocele.

Option c : Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. The image below shows a newborn with cystic hygroma on the right side of the neck.

Option D: Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. 

The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypotension with no presence of bleeding and bilateral adrenalectomy is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to a precipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands. It presents with non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominal emergency.

Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitary pathology- lack of ACTH) or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH). Adrenal crisis requires immediate intervention owing to its high mortality rate. Immediate rehydration is initiated with a saline infusion at 1 litre/hr with continuous cardiac monitoring. 

Other options :

Option b : SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) involves excessive secretion of ADH despite normal or low plasma osmolality. This causes water retention, diluting serum sodium, and increasing urine osmolality. The resultant fluid overload can cause nausea, vomiting, and low BUN.

Option c : Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. 

Option d : Cerebral salt wasting syndrome results from hypersecretion of atrial natriuretic peptide. It is seen primarily with central nervous system disorders including brain tumors, head trauma, hydrocephalus, neurosurgery, cerebrovascular accidents, and brain death. It is associated with hyponatremia, polyuria and elevated urinary sodium excretion. Treatment is by restoring intravascular volume with sodium chloride and water.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with a painless swelling in the neck. Histopathological examination reveals the following findings as shown in image below and she is diagnosed with follicular cell carcinoma, with involvement of level VI neck lymph nodes. What would be the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation
Total thyroidectomy with lateral neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of follicular thyroid carcinoma wih level VI neck lymph node involvement, total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection is the appropriate management.

The histopathological image with sheets of cells forming follicles with capsular invasion is shown below.

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is the most common thyroid cancer in iodine-deficient areas. Peak incidence occurs between 40-60 years of age. It is more common in females. It usually presents as a solitary nodule, which is well-encapsulated.

It has a hematogenous spread. The most common site of distant metastasis is Bones > Lung. Osteolytic, pulsatile bone metastasis is seen due to hypervascularity.  

Diagnosis of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) requires demonstration of capsular or vascular or lymphatic invasion which cannot be determined with Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB). So, follicular thyroid adenoma cannot be differentiated from Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) via FNAB.

Total thyroidectomy is recommended in case of high-risk features such as,

  • Older patients (>40 years of age) with follicular lesions >4 cm.
  • Capsular, Vascular, or lymphatic invasion.
  • Family history, metastases, atypia.
  • History of radiation exposure

Management of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is as follows:

Total Thyroidectomy :

  • 2-4 cm Tumor size with high-risk features or Capsular, Lymphatic, Vascular invasion.

  •  >4cm Tumor size.

Hemithyroidectomy:

  • ≤ 2 cm Tumor size.
  • 2-4 cm Tumor size without high-risk features.
     

Lymph node involvement is not common. Hence, prophylactic neck dissection is not needed.

If central lymph nodes are involved - Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection.

If other lymph nodes are involved - Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection (option c ).

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

(Fulfilling all 5 of the following conditions)

  1. < 40 years (better prognosis)
  2. Unifocal lesion
  3. Size < 2 cm
  4. No lymphovascular invasion
  5. No capsular invasion

High- risk DTC without LN involvement
(not fulfilling all of the above 5 conditions)

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining blunt abdominal trauma while riding his two-wheeler. A CECT scan reveals a laceration of the spleen greater than 3 cm, accompanied by a subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the surface area. According to the AAST Spleen Injury Scale, how would you grade this injury?
questions.solution:
Any injury in the presence of laceration of the spleen greater than 3 cm, accompanied by a subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the surface area is considered as Grade III as per the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale.

The spleen is the most commonly injured organ in blunt trauma to the abdomen. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale.

Management of Splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

  • They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively.
  • Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals and serial CECT.
  • If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis.
  • If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable or if there is a contrast blush, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of Grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of Grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries: These patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Billroth's II procedure.

In Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease. It is used to treat gastric cancer, duodenal ulcer disease, refractory peptic ulcer disease and gastric adenocarcinoma.

The Billroth II gastrojejunostomy procedure is shown in the image below.

Other options :

Option a : The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when the entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or if tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach. The structures removed during whipple procedure are shown in the image below.

 

Option c : Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image below.

Option d : Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy as shown below.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids for the past nine months. A barium swallow test was performed, and the results are shown in the accompanying image. Based on the Chicago classification, what are the accurate statements?

1.Type I is classical type associated with nonrelaxing LOS and absent peristalsis in the body of the oesophagus. 

2.Type II is associated with absent peristalsis and Pan esophageal pressurisation.

3.Type III is associated with premature spastic contractions with DCI >450 mmHg·s·cm with ≥20% of swallows.

4.Type III is associated with premature spastic contractions with DCI >540 mmHg·s·cm with ≥20% of swallows.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia and according to Chicago classification option d is correct, which includes statement 1,2,3 as follows.

  1. Type I is classical type associated with nonrelaxing LOS and absent peristalsis in the body of the oesophagus.
  2. Type II is associated with absent peristalsis and Pan esophageal pressurisation.
  3. Type III is associated with premature spastic contractions with DCI >450 mmHg·s·cm with ≥20% of swallows.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing.
  • High resting LES pressure.
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis.

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a bird's beak at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 24 hr pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Medical management with sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, and calcium-channel blockers for symptomatic relief. Pneumatic dilatation and Botox injection

Surgical management is treatment of choice :

  • Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the definitive management - The major complication associated with this procedure is gastro-oesophageal reflux. So it is best to combine it with partial anterior fundoplication (Heller–Dor operation).
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
  • Open Esophageal Myotomy - rarely done. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: A 4-year-old-boy was brought to emergency department with complaints of acute radiating pain in right iliac region and during surgery the following structure was found. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image are both suggestive of Meckel's Diverticulum.

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. It is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

The rule of 2's (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :

  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)(Option d).
  • 2% incidence
  • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
  • approximately 2 inches in length
  • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age

The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years. Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

A bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa. 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of the failure of normal regression of vitellointestinal duct:

Other Options:

Option A: The most common tumor of the appendix is the well-differentiated neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix.

Option B: Adenocarinoma of  the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. They are detected in 0.08 to 0.1% of appendectomy specimens. Mucinous is a subtype of the adenocarinoma of  the appendix.

Option D: In bowel loop obstruction, the obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and lie transversely. In cases of jejunal obstruction, valvulae conniventes, which are mucosal folds that span the entire diameter of the bowel, create a ladder effect. Additionally, a distended cecum may exhibit a gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/ Hernia-en-W/ retrograde hernia, it has two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac forming a "W" shape. The center portion of the 'W' loop is strangulated and it lies within the abdominal cavity.

Option a: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option b: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content.

Option c: In pantaloon hernia, both direct and indirect hernia occur on the same side.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is scheduled to receive parenteral nutrition via central venous access following a significant ileal resection. All the following are true except?

choices.text: For longer-term parenteral nutrition, Hickman lines are preferable
Peripherally inserted central venous catheter (PICC) lines have a mean duration of survival of 7 days
The catheter tip lies in the proximal superior vena cava

questions.solution:
In the scenario provided, the statement that "the catheter tip lies in the proximal superior vena cava" is false. The correct positioning is in the distal superior vena cava.

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is the provision of all nutritional requirements via the intravenous route, without utilizing the gastrointestinal tract.

Indications: TPN is indicated when a patient’s energy and protein needs cannot be met through enteral feeding. Common clinical scenarios include:

  • Massive resection of the small intestine
  • Presence of intestinal fistulae
  • Prolonged intestinal failure for other reasons

TPN can be administered through:

Central Venous Catheter:

  • Inserted via the subclavian vein (Option c) or internal/external jugular vein.
  • Preferred for long-term parenteral nutrition.
  • Hickman lines are commonly used for long term parenteral nutrition (Option a) and are inserted with fluoroscopic or ultrasound guidance.
  • These lines include a small cuff to minimize line dislodgement and reduce the risk of line sepsis.

Peripheral Line:

  • Appropriate for short-term feeding (up to 2 weeks).
  • Can be administered via a dedicated catheter (PICC line) or a conventional short cannula in a peripheral vein.
  • PICC lines have a mean duration of survival of about 7 days (Option b ).
  • Disadvantage is thrombophlebitis.

Catheter Tip Positioning:

  • A post-insertion chest X-ray is essential to confirm the absence of pneumothorax.
  • Correct positioning of the catheter tip in the distal superior vena cava to minimize the risk of central venous or cardiac thrombosis.
     

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycemia/hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: A 25 year old male complaints of a painful midline swelling persistent since many years associated with clear watery discharge since 1 week. On examination, the swelling moves with protrusion of tongue and deglutition. What is the acquired complication associated with the given condition?

choices.text: Papillary cell carcinoma of thyroid gland

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst and thyroglossal fistula is the acquired complication of Thyroglossal cyst. 

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct: 

Beneath foramen cecum → Floor of mouth → Suprahyoid → Region of thyroid cartilage → Subhyoid (most common site)

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant.
  • Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen cecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

Other options :

Option a : Papillary cell carcinoma of thyroid gland is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and those exposed to ionizing radiation. The mean age of presentation is a 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea are associated with local invasion. It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan.

Option b : Infection is the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst.

Option d : Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling.

questions.text: During rounds, a surgery resident instructed the intern to closely monitor the burns patient for proper fluid resuscitation. What is the best parameter to assess the adequacy of fluid resuscitation in a patient?
questions.solution:
Urine output is the best parameter to monitor adequacy of fluid resuscitation and is the best measure of end organ perfusion.

Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of  >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, it does not give a minute-to-minute value.

Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%. If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include, restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries and high hematocrit.

The average normal urine output is approximately 1500 mL/day. A minimum urine output of 400 mL/day is essential to excrete the end products of protein metabolism.

Fluid loss occurs mainly by four routes:

  • Lungs: Approximately 400 mL of water is lost in expired air every 24 hours.
  • Skin: In a temperate climate the loss is between 600 and 1000 mL/day.
  • Urine: The normal urine output is approximately 1500 mL/day.
  • Faeces: About 60 and 150 mL of water are lost daily in patients with normal bowel function.

The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion.

The only clinical indicators of perfusion of the gastrointestinal tract and muscular beds are measures of lactic acidosis (lactate and base deficit) and mixed venous oxygen saturation.

Other options:

Option A: Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, used for estimation of preload and right atrial pressure.

Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm H2O). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and may be given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable in assessing volume status or left ventricular function with respect to resusitation.

Options C and D: Blood pressure and oxygen saturation do not reflect body fluid levels.

questions.text: What is the best position for the patient to be in while inserting the given tube for enteral feeds?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Ryle's tube and the best position for this patient during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

Nasogastric tube/ Ryle's tube is used to provide enteral feeds. It is also used to diagnose the patency of the esophagus in conditions like tracheoesophageal fistula. If enteral feeds are continued for more than a week then a fine bore tube is used. It is inserted by standing perpendicular to the patient and the distance is calculated using the NEX method.

NEX method :
  • The tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air and X-ray chest. 

Indications for NG tube are aspiration of gastric fluid, gastric decompression, zollinger ellison syndrome, feeding and medicine administration. Contraindications for NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery and basilar skull fractures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 3 month which is not responding to antibiotics. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On examination of breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. Mammography shows the following finiding. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with mammography showing broken needle calcification is suggestive of duct ectasia, Hadfield’s operation is the next best step in management of duct ectasia as the condition is not resolving with antibiotics.

Duct ectasia is the focal dilatation of the lactiferous ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking.The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions which is shown in the image below: 

 

In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, due to irritation, causing periductal mastitis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Mammography showing the characteristic broken needle calcification which is shown in the image below:

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation (cone Excision of the major ducts). This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

Option b : Webster operation is a circum-areolar operation done for the excision of fibroadenoma.

questions.text: Considering the distinctive radiological finding presented below, what is the most probable diagnosis, and what is the suggested management?

choices.text: Acute pancreatitis, intravenous fluids and pain management
Chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic enzyme replacement and pain management
Pancreatic cancer, surgical resection or chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The given image shows the chain of lakes appearance in the biliary tree. This is seen in chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy is indicated to manage digestive insufficiency, while pain management strategies are crucial for symptom control.

The chain of lakes appearance is due to a dilated main duct with clubbing and dilatation of the side branches - due to scarring and strictures in the pancreatic duct caused by repeated inflammation. 

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. Patients can present with steatorrhoea i.e., the passage of offensive-smelling large stools due to fat malabsorption. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1. ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. 

Other options:

Option A: Acute pancreatitis caused by gallstones or alcohol can present with pancreatic edema and inflammation. Acute pancreatitis is not associated with strictures and obstruction. CT shows acute interstitial pancreatitis with diffuse swelling of the pancreas and peripancreatic inflammatory changes (arrows). The pancreas was well-perfused without evidence of necrosis.


Option C: Pancreatic cancer typically presents with irregular ductal narrowing or masses, not the beaded and dilated appearance of the chain of lakes sign. Surgical resection or chemotherapy are treatment options for pancreatic cancer, depending on the stage and spread of the disease.


Option D: Pancreatic pseudocysts appear as fluid-filled collections separate from the ductal system, unlike the chain of lakes pattern within the duct itself. Percutaneous drainage is a minimally invasive procedure for managing symptomatic pseudocysts.

    • Precipitated by food intake: So, weight loss is seen.

  • Exocrine insufficiency:

    • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.

questions.text: A 42-year old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is suggestive of Pneumoperitoneum and the likely cause for this would be peptic ulcer perforation.

Gastric ulcers are more prone to perforate than bleed. Thus, these perforations lead to pneumoperitoneum which is an emergency and warrants immediate surgical intervention. 

The classical description of a patient with a perforated peptic ulcer is described in three stages:

Stage of peritonism: Initial 6 hours - patient presents with an acute burning epigastric pain with or without vomiting. Leakage of gastric acid into the peritoneal cavity causes diaphragmatic irritation which may lead to pain referred to the shoulder tip (Option D) and tracking of fluid in the right para-colic gutter may lead to right iliac fossa pain. Abdominal guarding with diminished abdominal movements on respiration is noted and the patient avoids movement to prevent pain. Tachycardia (Option B) is noted but pyrexia does not set in.
Stage of reaction: the symptoms temporarily subside due to the dilution of the exudate in the peritoneal cavity but abdominal rigidity remains (Option A).
Stage of diffuse peritonitis: sunken face, hollow cheeks, dry mucous membranes (facies hippocratica) with fever, tachycardia, low volume pulse and increasing abdominal distension.
Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Perforation is an indication for surgical exploration. Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily with an omental patch repair, while larger perforations may require a distal gastrectomy with a roux-en-y reconstruction. Patients require prolonged PPI therapy postoperatively.

 Other options: 

A. Tension pneumothorax - presents with a rapid hemodynamic compromise with absent breath sounds. Pneumoperitoneum rarely is caused by pneumothorax, and downward displacement of air is more likely seen in retroperitoneal spaces.

C. Boerhaave syndrome or spontaneous esophageal rupture - occurs in alcoholics after binge drinking, due to forced vomiting from the closed glottis.  Pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema are seen here. 

D. Mallory Weis tear - longitudinal mucosal tear resulting in upper GI bleeding. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

questions.text: All of the following are the advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split-thickness skin graft except ____

choices.text: It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements
The most commonly used donor site is the thigh
The donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns

questions.solution:
All the following are advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split-thickness skin graft except, the "donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns". It is advantage of split-thickness skin graft not full-thickness skin graft.

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ) is a partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft :

  • Large grafts can be harvested.In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns (Option d ).
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up.
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft :

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction (Option a ).
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements (Option b ).
  • The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children.
  • The most commonly used donor site is the thigh (Option c ).

questions.text: A 65 year old patient with a history of chronic smoking came with complaints of ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for a year. She is diagnosed with squamous cell cancer involving  >2/3rd of lip. Management is done using the flap reconstruction surgery, as shown in image below. Identify the flap used?
questions.solution:
The patient has squamous cell carcinoma affecting more than two-thirds of the lip, and the treatment involves reconstruction using an Abbe-Estlander flap. It is  based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years old but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. Mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. Loss of sensation over the chin indicates mental nerve involvement. The most frequently involved nodes are the submental and submandibular nodes.

Surgical resection (wide local excision with negative margins) is the preferred treatment modality. The typical lip length is 6 to 7 cm. For defects of <1/3rd of the lip, resection with primary closure is the preferred treatment.

For defects of more than 1/3rd of the lip, require local flaps for reconstruction after resection:

  • Johansen step technique- local flap for large central defects 
  • Lip-switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap- based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects. The markings of the Abbe-Estlander flap are shown below.
  • Karapandzic flap - circumoral advancement flap. It is a neuromuscular flap that includes the remaining orbicularis oris muscle with its innervation.

In the presence of neck metastasis, neck dissection is indicated. Postoperative radiation is administered to patients with positive margins, lymph node metastases, tumor thickness >4mm, or perineural invasion. If the mandible is involved, mandibulectomy and free flap reconstruction is required.

Other options : 

Option a : Free fibular flap - It is a free flap(flaps taken from one site and placed in another). Used in mandibular reconstruction and is based on peroneal vessels.

Option b : PMMC flap - Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is a m/c used flap in head & neck reconstruction surgery.

Option c : Deltopectoral flap - Composed of fascia, subcutaneous tissue and skin but does not contain muscle. It is used as an alternative to PMMC flap for soft tissue reconstruction of mandible and maxilla.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident (RTA) is on examination. He opens his eyes on verbal command, and abnormal flexion of limbs is noted. He speaks inappropriate words, and both pupils are reactive to light. Calculate his GCS-pupil score.
questions.solution:
The GCS-pupil score of the above-mentioned patient is 9.

The GCS-pupil score is calculated as the difference between GCS and the pupil reactivity score (PRS). Here, the score according to the GCS is 9 and calculated as:

  • Eye opening to verbal command is 3.
  • Verbal response with inappropriate words is 3.
  • Motor response with abnormal flexion of limbs is 3.
  • The pupil reactivity score (PRS) ranges from 0 to 2, where both the pupils are reactive to light, the score is taken as 0.

Thereby, the GCS-pupil score becomes : GCS - PRS = 9-0 = 9.

The Glasgow coma scale-pupil score is the incorporation of pupillary function into the GCS. The changes in pupil reactivity can influence the overall assessment of neurological status provided by the GCS. Pupil reactivity indicates the function of the brainstem, which controls basic vital functions such as breathing and heart rate.

questions.solution:

Czerny’s Retractor is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

questions.text: As a 1st-year resident surgeon, you are operating on a 30-year-old patient with unilateral cystic scrotal swelling which is brilliantly transilluminating. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of hydrocele and eversion of the sac upon itself, should be done in this case of hydrocele.

A hydrocele is due to fluid accumulation between the 2 layers of tunica vaginalis. It may be primary or secondary depending on whether it is due to defective absorption or excess formation. Eversion of the sac causes the production of fluid towards the outside which can be absorbed by outer scrotal layers.

Management is by eversion of the sac upon itself, also known as jabolay's procedure. The other method of treating the hydrocele is plicating the redundant tunica and can be done when the sac wall is thin. This is known as Lord's operation.

Other options:

Option a : Excision of the sac is not recommended as it is liable to bleed and cause a scrotal hematoma.
Option b : Ligation of the scrotal vein will impair the venous drainage and result in ischemia or edema.
Option d : Percutaneous drainage of fluid is not a long term solution as the fluid will reappear within a week.

questions.text: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by?

questions.solution:
Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the oscillation of water column in the tube. 

During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known as tidaling.

An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the 5th intercostal space (ICS) in midaxillary line in adults and in paediactric age group it is placed at at 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line.

Option B: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its functioning.

Option C: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive male presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. He was started on anti-hypertensives. A CT chest of the patient showed aortic dissection limited to the descending aorta. The patient had persistent pain despite adequate medical therapy. questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a penetrating chest injury is undergoing an emergency thoracotomy. Due to insufficient cardiac output during the procedure, an open cardiac massage is being performed. What category does this type of surgical wound fall under?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a 40-year-old patient with a penetrating chest trauma is undergoing an emergency thoracotomy, and the open cardiac massage performed is classified as a contaminated wound.

Contaminated wounds are class III surgical wounds. They include fresh open accidental wounds, surgeries with a major break in sterile technique, gross spillage of the gastrointestinal tract, or incision through an inflamed nonpurulent tissue. Examples include:

  • Open cardiac massage
  • Penetrating abdominal trauma

  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases.

Diagnosis of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases includes clinical examination findings of weakened pulses below the level of obstruction, reduced ABPI <0.9, Duplex scan and color doppler. Digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard investigation. CT angiography and MR angiography can be done for extent and type of obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presents with a crush injury to the lower limb, and the doctor is worried about the risk of gangrene and sepsis. What factors can assist in determining whether to proceed with amputation or attempt to save the limb?

The factors which can assist in determining whether to proceed with amputation or attempt to save the limb is Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).

Components of MESS include :

  • Ischemia
  • Velocity
  • Age

Total score is 11. A score 6 or less is consistent with a salvageable limb.

Other scores to assess if the limb is salvageable or not include, limb salvage index, Ganga score.

Other options:

Option a : Gustilo Anderson Classification is used to classify open fractures.

Option b : Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in initial assessment of consciousness in an emergent patient.

Option d : Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines are used in assessment and resuscitation of injured patients.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe anorectal pain during and after defecation. The pain was present for 6 months but has increased in severity over the past 1 day. Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.

Surgery is indicated in: 

  1. Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
  2. Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
  3. Early grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

  3. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy - is circumferential rectal mucosectomy. It is associated with reduced postoperative pain, faster recovery and shorter hospital stay

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents with nausea, fever and pain in right iliac fossa. CT scan reveals well circumscribed fluid collection in the right iliac fossa. What could be the next best step in management?

choices.text: Radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by interval appendicectomy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with CT scan showing well circumscribed fluid collection in right iliac fossa is suggestive of appendicular abscess and next best step in management include radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by delayed appendicectomy.

An appendicular abscess is a very common complication of an untreated or perforated appendix. It can occur retroperitoneally or intraperitoneally. Investigations include USG or CT of the abdomen which shows a well-circumscribed, rounded, irregular fluid collection in the appendicular region. 

With the recent advances, early laparoscopic drainage or radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by delayed appendicectomy is also done. If these are unsuccessful or there is leakage into the peritoneal cavity a midline laparotomy can be done. 

Other options :

Option a : Ochsner–Sherren regimen is conservative management and it comprises hospitalization, intravenous fluids, antibiotics, analgesics, and a strict watch on the vitals and general state of the patient. A s the patient has already developed appendicular abcess it wont be helpful.

Option b : Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder.

Option c : Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain. He gives a history of weight loss for 3 months. Barium enema shows the following picture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. It arises from the adenomatous polyps after a mutation sequence of adenoma-carcinoma influenced by environmental factors. Most colon cancers occur in the left colon. The clinical features of colon carcinoma include a change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon.

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice in suspected colorectal carcinoma. Double-contrast barium enema shows a constant irregular filling defect known as the apple core appearance. Computed tomography (CT) virtual colonoscopy has replaced barium enema as it is highly sensitive. Spiral CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is now the standard means for staging colon cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man complained of sudden pain in his scrotum with a fever. His condition rapidly deteriorated and he presented with findings as shown below. What is the correct sequence of steps in the management of this patient?

choices.text: IV fluids > IV antibiotics  > surgical debridement > skin grafting
IV antibiotics  >  IV fluids > surgical debridement > skin grafting
Surgical debridement  > IV fluids > IV antibiotics > skin grafting
Surgical debridement > skin grafting > iv fluids > iv antibiotics

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image findings of cellulitis of the testis are suggestive of fournier's gangrene and the next best steps in the management of this condition are IV fluids > IV antibiotics  > surgical debridement > skin grafting.

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode. 

Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc.  SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin can also cause Fournier's gangrene. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected. It is a surgical emergency. Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene is as follows:

A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus is seen (as shown below).

questions.text: Regarding varicose veins, which of the following statement is true ______

choices.text: The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the long saphenous vein
The saphenous nerve is closely associated with short saphenous vein
Vein of giacomini, connects the small saphenous vein with the great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding varicose veins is, vein of Giacomini, connects the small saphenous vein (SSV) with the great saphenous vein (GSV).

The sural nerve accompanies the SSV laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of SSV.

The Saphenous nerve accompanies the GSV medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of GSV.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of  pain in right upper abdomen with yellowish discolouration of eyes. The ultrasound finding is given below. According to WHO classification the cyst belongs to which of the following type?
questions.solution:
The given USG showing the hydatid cyst with multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance, it is classified as CE 2 according to the WHO classification and Type III according to the Gharbi classification.

Classification of hepatic hydatid cysts is given in the image below.

Hydatid Cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species(dog tapeworm ). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary.

CT scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. Diagnosis is suggested by the finding of a multiloculated cyst on ultrasound and is further supported by the finding of a floating membrane within the cysts on a CT scan. Active cysts contain a large number of smaller daughter cysts (multi-vesicular rosette-like cystic lesions with daughter cysts) which is characteristic of hydatid cysts of the liver.

If there is a disruption of the inner layers of the cyst, the following signs may be noted:

  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane (as shown below)
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed 

The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below), it is classified as WHO CE 2 or Gharbi type III.

Other options :

Option a : WHO CE 3a or Gharbi Type II - water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.

Option b : WHO CE 3B or Gharbi type III - Cyst with daughter cyst in solid matrix.

Option d : WHO CE 4 or Gharbi Type IV - Cyst with heterogenous hypoechoic or hyperechoic contents. No daughter cyst.

questions.text: Symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome can be reproduced when the patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and asked to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. This provocative test is called?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos test (Extended arm stress test).

Roos test or EAST Test (Extended Arm Stress Test):

Method:

  • The patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation postion.
  • The patient is to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period.

Inference:

  • Reproduction of symptoms suggests compression.

The following image below demonstrates the Roos test.

Provocative tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome:

Adson test (Scalene Manoeuvre):

Method:

The examiner locates the radial pulse and the patient is asked to:

  • Turn the head towards the affected side
  • Extend the neck
  • Take deep breath and hold

Inference:

A positive test is indicated by a disappearance of the pulse.

Halsted Test (Costoclavicular Manoeuvre):

Method:

  • The examiner locates the radial pulse and draws the patient's shoulder down and back as the patient lifts their chest in an exaggerated "attention" posture.

Inference:

  • A positive test is indicated by an absence of a pulse.

Wright Test (Hyperabduction Manoeuvre)

Method:

  • Patients arm is hyperabducted to 180o and externally rotated

Inference:

  • Loss of radial pulse suggests compression

Allen Test:

Method:

  • The patient is asked to clench both fists tightly for 1 minute at the same time.
  • Pressure is applied over both radial arteries simultaneously so as to occlude them.
  • The patient then opens the fingers of both hands rapidly, and the examiner compares the colour of both. The initial pallor should be replaced quickly by rubor.
  • The test may be repeated, this time occluding the ulnar arteries.

Inference:

  • If the artery is occluded, the colour does not return and pallor remains longer on the affected side.

questions.text: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with pelvic fracture and is suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I

questions.solution:
The true statement is Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

It consists of three phases:

  1. Phase I - Initial Exploration : This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active haemorrhage and contamination.
  2. Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation : This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis.
  3. Phase III - Definitive Operation : It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Other options :

Option b : Definitive repair of injuries is  not done 12-24 hours after phase III. Re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries is done in phase III and this phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.


 Option c : Internal iliac artery ligation is not done in phase II, it is done in phase I.

Option d : Hypothermia and acidosis are not corrected in phase I, but corrected in phase II.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

  1. Patient selection
  2. Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination
  3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
  4. Deﬁnitive surgery
  5. Abdominal closure

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

Upon investigation, serum calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are elevated, while phosphate levels are low. An X-ray of the skull reveals the findings shown in the image. choices.text: Salt and pepper skull - Primary Hyperparathyroidism

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient with recurrent kidney stones, abdominal cramps and mood swings is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism and the xray skull reveals salt and pepper skull appearance.

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone. The image given below shows a salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect.
    • Salt and pepper skull.
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease.
  • Stones:
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common.
    • Nephrocalcinosis.
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis.
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms.
  • Features of hypercalcemia - vomiting, confusion, ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval.

Investigations in primary hyperparathyroidism includes,

  • Lab investigations reveal elevated serum calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and reduced phosphate level.
  • Ultrasonography of the neck, which is a safe and widely used technique for localising abnormal parathyroid glands.
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry (DEXA) is useful for demonstrating skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabelled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the hospital by his wife following a road traffic accident. On examination, blood is noted at the meatus, and  digital rectal examination reveals a high-riding prostate. Further investigations reveal the findings shown in the accompanying image. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) shows contrast leakage at the membranous urethra and the next best step in management will be suprapubic catheterisation.

Membranous urethral rupture usually occurs following a road traffic accident, crush injury, or a fall. It is associated with pelvic fracture and extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

The clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and a high riding prostate on digital rectal examination. There is typically marked bruising of the pubic area, scrotum and penis. If the diagnosis is suspected, a Retrograde urethrogram(RGU) performed with water-soluble contrast media is confirmatory.

A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as practicable using the Seldinger technique. The distended bladder may be palpable, making suprapubic catheterisation straightforward, but often the bruising and swelling associated with the fracture makes this difficult and ultrasound guidance is required. When suprapubic urinary diversion has been achieved then no further urological management is required until the patient has stabilised. In the presence of a coexisting extraperitoneal bladder injury, no bladder will be apparent on ultrasound examination, and surgical exploration, bladder repair, suprapubic catheter placement and drainage of the retropubic space is needed.

Option c : Foleys catheter insertion should not be done in cases of suspected urethral injury, as it can convert a partial tear into a complete tear.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a painless ulcer on her scalp that hasn't healed for 10 years. She reported an electrical burn injury to the scalp 10 years ago. Based on the examination findings provided, what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing a long-standing ulcer with crusting and irregular borders can progress to Marjolin's ulcer which is an aggressive type of squamous cell carcinoma(SCC)  and Surgical excision is the treatment of choice.

Marjolin ulcers most commonly arise from burn scars. The most common cell type identified is squamous cell carcinoma. All suspicious lesions should be biopsied. Confirmed cases of Marjolin ulcers should be excised with clear margins. Marjolin ulcers can be prevented with early excision and grafting of burn wounds. The prognosis is poor with a high rate of recurrence. 

SCC is the second most common skin cancer. The primary risk factor and driving force for the development of this common cancer is UV exposure. Variants of SCC include, Bowen's disease and Erythroplasia of Queyrat. It initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. All these lesions later ulcerate and have a characteristic everted edge and are surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities include cautery ablation, cryotherapy, drug therapy including imiquimod, Moh’s microsurgery and Radiation therapy.

The image below shows the varieties of ulcer edge and conditions associated.

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma arising from
    • Long-standing ulcer like venous ulcer
    • Post-burn scar
    • Chronic osteomyelitis
    • Post-radiation ulcer.
  • Slow progression to malignancy (SCC) since it is relatively avascular.
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue.
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue.
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity.

questions.text: A young male seeking to study abroad has a chest X-ray taken for immigration purposes, which reveals air beneath both domes of the diaphragm. He shows no symptoms and has normal vital signs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an asymptomatic patient having air under the diaphragm without evidence of peritonitis (sterile pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of pneumatosis intestinalis.

Pneumatosis Intestinalis presents as multiple gas filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract. Most common site is jejunum>ileocecal region >colon. It has Equal incidence among males and females and it most commonly occurs in the 4th-7th decades of life. Pneumatosis in neonates is usually associated with necrotizing enterocolitis. The histiopathological finding shows a honeycomb appearance with thin walled cyst ehich break easily and spontaneous rupture of cyst give rise to pneumoperitoneum.

Clinical features are mostly nonspecific,most commonly diarrhea, abdominal pain, abdominal distention, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and mucus in stools. Diagnosis on plain films is radiolucent areas within the bowel wall (appear as grape-like clusters or tiny bubbles) and alternatively, barium contrast or CT studies can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment include, management of the uncomplicated primary disease and when symptoms demand treatment, the first line is intermittent high flow oxygen therapy, providing a concentration of 70% continuously for 5 days by nasal specula. The cysts may also resolve with antibiotics, particularly metronidazole and in resistant cases, maintenance treatment with sulfasalazine may be helpful. 

The image given below is the plain xray showing air under diaphragm and radiolucent areas within the bowel wall.

 

Other options :

Option b : Diverticulitis on CT abdomen shows bright bowel outpouching, which may be complicated by infection and abscess formation.

Option c : In Peptic ulcer perforation, the supine abdominal x-ray shows air beneath the diaphragm along with Rigler's double-wall sign indicating pneumoperitoneum, as shown in the image given below. Consumption of alcohol and chronic tobacco smoking are high-risk factors for developing peptic ulcers. Fever and tachycardia suggest peritonitis from the perforated ulcer. 

Option d : Duodenal atresia is caused by the failure of vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is commonly seen in newborns with Down’s syndrome. Babies usually present with bilious vomiting immediately after birth. A plain X-ray abdomen reveals two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum called the double bubble sign (as shown below).

questions.text: While on rounds in the post-operative ward,  you observe your senior teaching a patient who has undergone an open cholecystectomy two days ago, to use this device. What is the main purpose of using this device?
questions.solution:
The purpose of incentive spirometry in a post-operative patient is to prevent pulmonary atelectasis.

Atelectasis, especially of the lower lobes, is the most common respiratory complication in a post-operative patient and can be prevented by sitting the patient or inclining the bed, early mobilization, deep breathing exercises with incentive spirometry, and chest physiotherapy. Patients who are not fully awake may require non-invasive mechanical ventilation with PEEP. Correct manner of performing incentive spirometry is by taking sequential deep breaths so that all the balls or marker in the tube rise to the top, holding the breath for 5-6 seconds, and then exhaling. 

The primary pathophysiology of is inadequate expansion of the alveoli leading to their collapse. The factors predisposing to atelectasis are general anesthesia, upper abdominal and thoracic surgery. In the post-operative period, inadequate pain control may lead to poor inspiratory effort and and reduced diaphragm contraction in the patient's attempt to avoid experiencing pain,  may also contribute to the development of atelectasis. On the other hand, overuse of opioid analgesics or sedatives may also favour development of atelectasis due to respiratory depression causing collection of secretions. Other causes include lack of mobilization (bed-bound patients) or positional change.

Patients present with tachypnoea and decreased oxygen saturation and on examination, the breath sounds are bronchial in nature and reduced in intensity. Chest xray may show diminished lung volume, linear opacities, and elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with an enlarging abdominal mass at the site of previous trauma for the past 1 month. The mass is firm and non-tender. After initial imaging, a core needle biopsy reveals the following histological findings. Which of the following conditions is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histological findings of long spindle cells in a collagenous stroma are suggestive of desmoid tumor and it is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Desmoid tumors (also known as aggressive fibromatosis) are fibroblastic neoplasms with aggressive infiltrative behavior but no metastatic potential. 10% to 15% of patients with FAP develop desmoid tumors. The risk is even greater for patients with Gardner's syndrome. Risk factors for sporadic disease include previous surgical incision, pregnancy, hormonal exposure, and trauma. They occur more commonly in females. 

These tumors can occur anywhere in the body but are most common in the abdomen and abdominal wall. They present as firm, painful, or non-painful masses, which may be either slow or rapidly growing. 

The investigation of choice is MRI. Histopathological diagnosis is done by a core-needle or incisional biopsy. Management involves observation for stable, asymptomatic, or recurrent desmoids. Surgery is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease, risk of invasion, or enlarging tumors.

Other options:

Option A: von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is associated with renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system, and pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with gastrointestinal carcinomas, breast cancer, testicular cancer, pancreatic cancer, and benign pigmentation of the skin and mucosa.

Option D: Cowden syndrome is associated with cancer of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyp usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present in 50% cases.
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma.
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) seen in 75% of cases; it is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma: In the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon accidentally injures the marked structure in image given below, mistaking it as cystic artery leading to intraoperative bleeding. What structure did the surgeon accidentally cut?
questions.solution:
In the given intra-operative image during laparoscopic cholecystectomy and  the structure marked which is accidentally injured is a tortuous right hepatic artery aka Moynihan's hump.

The tortuous hepatic artery is the anomalous structure which the surgeon accidentally cut during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Tortuosity of the hepatic artery is an anomaly present in front of the origin of the cystic duct or right hepatic artery is tortuous and the cystic duct is short, this tortuosity is known as ‘caterpillar turn’ or ‘Moynihan’s hump’. It is an important anomaly that should be recognized in order to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries. 

During Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the importance of achieving a critical view of safety is paramount for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and artery.  It can be achieved by following these 3 principles:

  • The hepatocystic triangle is cleared of fat and fibrous tissue. The hepatocystic triangle is defined as the triangle formed by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior edge of the liver. The common bile duct and common hepatic duct do not have to be exposed.
  • The lower one-third of the gallbladder is separated from the liver to expose the cystic plate. The cystic plate is also known as liver bed of the gallbladder and lies in the gallbladder fossa.
  •  Only two structures should be seen entering the gallbladder.

The inferior surface of the liver does not form the boundary of Calot’s triangle. It forms the superior boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are: 3C's

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery

questions.text: A patient presents with flank pain and hematuria. The histology slide of the patient is provided. Based on the clinical presentation and histological findings, which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. It can be identified by the presence of pale eosinophilic cells arranged in the form of solid sheets with some cells having a perinuclear halo as shown in the image below.

Chromophobe carcinoma is thought to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. It shows large cells having a plant cell like appearance. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers.

Option a : Clear cell RCC has the clear appearance of the cytoplasm due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids. The below image shows clear cell renal carcinoma:

Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option d : Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla.
